titleInfo.title: Only Friends Can Betray You
titleInfo.subTitle: Domestic Political Shocks and Interstate Conflict Behavior

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.abstract: In this dissertation I introduce a novel argument that applies Prospect Theory to explain how changes in the domestic politics of a state can influence onset and termination of international conflict. I demonstrate that it is only when states share a very close ex-ante relationship, that domestic political shocks should be expected to lead to conflict ex-post. Revolution and other forms of dramatic political change in a State A damage the interests of other States B to the extent that they held close economic and security ties with the previous regime that can be damaged. These losses place the leadership of State B in a domain of losses We should expect decisionmakers inhabiting a domain of losses to exhibit risk-tolerant behavior, including preferences in favor of conflict. However, when states are already engaged in a hostile ex-ante relationship, I argue that domestic political shocks –like regime change –clearly demonstrate to outside states that the future policymaking process in the country has been severed from the previous conflictual policymaking process. This allows leaders to overcome natural risk aversion and seek out more conciliatory relations with the now reformed state. I test this theory in three empirical chapters. The first chapter demonstrates that domestic political shocks like revolution do indeed lead to rivalry onset, but as predicted by prospect theory, this is only true for states that were closely aligned –sharing alliance ties, high levels of trade, or high levels of foreign-policy alignment –prior to revolution in one state. In the second empirical chapter I demonstrate that, as predicted, only major change in the governing institutions of a state engaged in rivalry is associated with rivalry termination. The independent effects of change in leaders, policies, and state preferences is to lengthen rivalry. The third empirical chapter examines escalation of disputes and the timing of violent episodes between states engaged in long-standing territorial disputes, and demonstrates that escalation and de-escalation of territorial disputes are similarly tied to domestic political shocks within one or both disputing states.
